sections.title: What to measure

sections.title: Big ideas to remember
sections.excerpt: AI is systems, not magic. A model is a component. The system is everything around it: data, interfaces, monitoring, fallbacks, and ownership. If the system is weak, a strong model just fails faster.

sections.title: Common mistakes and myths
sections.excerpt: Bigger models are not always better. Bigger can mean slower, more expensive, and harder to operate. Sometimes a smaller model with a better data path wins.

sections.title: Mental models that actually help
sections.excerpt: If you are stuck, return to input, model, output. What inputs does the system really see. What does the model output. What happens next. Many failures are a mismatch between what the team thinks is happening and what is actually wired up.

Label PII, secrets, and operational telemetry separately. - **Application**: Enforce least privilege in code paths. Prefer signed tokens over shared secrets. Short TTLs, zero implicit

sections.title: How to study
sections.excerpt: 1. Skim the overview, then jump into the RSA lab to verify your cryptographic assumptions. 2. Use the CIA traceability list below as your checklist during architecture reviews. 3. Share your own playbooks by dropping new MDX lessons into .

sections.title: CIA traceability checklist
sections.excerpt: - Confidentiality: classification present, key management defined, access logged and alerting active. - Integrity: signed artefacts, reproducible builds, change control with approvals. - Availability: capacity plan, DoS strategy, backup + restore tested with RTO/RPO targets.

sections.title: Signals that matter
sections.excerpt: - **Network (OSI 3-4)**: flow logs, TLS fingerprints, rate anomalies. - **Application (OSI 5-7)**: auth failures by IP, token reuse, impossible travel, schema misuse. - **Platform (OSI 1-2)**: CPU throttling, packet drops, kernel logs, node restarts.

sections.title: Build the response muscle
sections.excerpt: 1. Create a "golden path" request and response sample for each critical user journey. 2. Write one detection per journey that flags data exfil, tampering, or abuse. 3. Simulate failure: kill a service, expire a token early, or inject a fake credential leak.

sections.title: Quick OSI-to-control map
sections.excerpt: - Physical/Data Link: link monitoring, port isolation, 802.1X. - Network: zero trust segmentation, egress allow-listing. - Transport: mTLS with rotated client certs, cipher suite policy. - Session/Presentation/Application: JWT expiry, content validation, WAF rules tuned to your domain vocabulary.

sections.title: Why RSA here?
sections.excerpt: RSA still underpins S/MIME, VPNs, and legacy identity providers. When you control the key lifecycle you control the blast radius.

sections.title: Generate a pair
sections.excerpt: Pick your modulus length. 2048 is balanced for most web apps; 4096 is safer but slower on constrained devices.

sections.title: Hardening tips
sections.excerpt: - Store private keys in an HSM or KMS where possible; if local, encrypt at rest and rotate. - Use different key pairs for transport (RSA-OAEP) and signing (RSA-PSS or ECDSA). - Keep PEMs short-lived. Automate rotation via CI/CD, and prefer mTLS between services for machine identity.

sections.title: Mathematical foundations of data systems
sections.excerpt: Maths in data systems describes patterns, uncertainty, and change. Abstraction turns messy reality into numbers we can reason about. At small scale numbers feel friendly. At large scale tiny errors compound and variation matters more than single values.

sections.title: Data models and abstraction at scale
sections.excerpt: Models are simplified representations of reality. They exist so teams can agree on how data fits together. Abstraction hides detail to make systems manageable. The risk is that hidden detail was needed for a decision you care about.

sections.title: Advanced analytics and inference
sections.excerpt: Inference is about drawing conclusions while admitting uncertainty. Correlation means two things move together; causation means one affects the other. Mistaking correlation for causation leads to confident but wrong decisions.

sections.title: Data platforms and distributed systems
sections.excerpt: Data systems distribute to handle scale and resilience. Latency is the time it takes to respond. Consistency is how aligned copies of data are. Failures are normal in distributed systems, so we plan for them instead of hoping they do not happen.

sections.title: Governance, regulation and accountability
sections.excerpt: Regulation exists to protect people and markets. Accountability means someone can explain what data is used, why, and with what safeguards. Auditability means we can trace who did what and when. These are not just legal boxes; they build trust with users and stakeholders.

sections.title: Data as a strategic and economic asset
sections.excerpt: Data creates value when it improves decisions, products, and relationships. Network effects appear when sharing makes each participant better off. Competitive advantage comes from combining quality data with disciplined execution, not from hoarding alone.

A sensor reading of 21°C is useless if the timestamp is missing. Noise is random variation that hides patterns, while signal is the meaningful part. sections.excerpt: Data starts at collection, gets stored, processed, shared, and eventually archived or deleted. Each step has design choices: where to store, how to process, how to secure, and when to retire. Software architecture cares about where components sit. Cybersecurity cares about protection at each hop. AI pipelines care about how raw data becomes features.

sections.title: Data architectures and pipelines
sections.excerpt: Data architecture is how data is organised, moved, and protected across systems. It sets the lanes so teams can build without tripping over each other. Pipelines exist because raw data is messy and scattered. They pull from sources, clean and combine, and land it where people and products can use it.

sections.title: Data governance and stewardship
sections.excerpt: Governance is agreeing how data is handled so people can work quickly without being reckless. Ownership is the person or team that decides purpose and access. Stewardship is the day to day care of definitions, quality, and metadata. Accountability means someone can explain how a change was made and why.

sections.title: Interoperability and standards
sections.excerpt: Interoperability means systems understand each other. It is shared meaning, not just shared pipes. Standards help: common formats, schemas, and naming. A schema is the agreed structure and data types. When systems misalign, data lands in the wrong fields, numbers become strings, or meaning gets lost.

sections.title: Data analysis and insight generation
sections.excerpt: Analysis is asking good questions of data and checking that the answers hold up. Descriptive thinking asks what happened. Diagnostic thinking asks why. Statistics exist to separate signal from noise: averages summarise, distributions show spread, trends show direction.

sections.title: Risk, ethics and strategic value
sections.excerpt: Data risk is broader than security. Misuse, misinterpretation, and neglect can harm people and decisions. Ethics asks whether we should use data in a certain way, not just whether we can. Strategic value comes from using data to improve services, not just to collect more of it.

sections.title: What software architecture actually is
sections.excerpt: Architecture is decision making under constraints. You are deciding what the system is allowed to do, what it must never do, and what it will trade to get there. The work is not drawing boxes. The work is picking the decisions that keep change affordable later.

sections.title: What this optimises for
sections.excerpt: - Shared understanding across a team - Cheaper change later through explicit decisions - Fewer surprises when systems grow or change hands

sections.title: What this makes harder
sections.excerpt: - You have to write decisions down and defend them - You might slow short term delivery to reduce long term risk

sections.title: After this section you should be able to:
sections.excerpt: - Explain what decision is being made in an architecture discussion, not just the diagram - Explain the trade off being accepted and what constraint caused it - Explain why clear decisions reduce risk for security, data, and AI systems

sections.title: Components, boundaries and interfaces
sections.excerpt: Architecture starts to become real when you can name the parts and explain how they talk. A component is not just a folder. It is a unit of responsibility with a purpose and a shape that can be explained.

sections.title: Layered architecture
sections.excerpt: Layering is common because it controls dependency direction. It reduces blast radius by keeping low level details from leaking into core logic. It also improves auditability because you can reason about where checks and decisions happen.

sections.title: Microservices vs monolith
sections.excerpt: This is not a morality contest. A monolith can be a good architecture if boundaries are clear and the deployment is reliable. Microservices can be a good architecture when independent scaling, team autonomy, or regulatory separation genuinely matter.

sections.title: Centralised vs decentralised data
sections.excerpt: Centralised data can reduce duplication and make reporting easier. Decentralised data can reduce coupling and allow components to evolve independently. The decision is not abstract. It changes who owns quality, who approves schema changes, and how incidents are investigated.

sections.title: After this section you should be able to:
sections.excerpt: - Explain why boundaries reduce change cost and security risk - Explain what breaks when interfaces are implicit or data ownership is unclear - Explain the trade off behind layering, microservices, and data ownership decisions

sections.title: Thinking in systems, not code
sections.excerpt: Most real failures are not inside one function. They happen in interactions: timeouts, retries, queue backlogs, and assumptions between services. A system can be correct in each part and still fail as a whole.

sections.title: What this optimises for
sections.excerpt: - Predictable behaviour under failure - Smaller incidents with clearer blast radius

sections.title: What this makes harder
sections.excerpt: - You must invest in guardrails, monitoring, and practice - Some optimisations are constrained by safety budgets

sections.title: AI automation vs human oversight
sections.excerpt: Automation can reduce workload and improve consistency. Oversight keeps accountability with people and catches failures before they scale. In real systems you usually want both: automation for low risk cases, and human review where the cost of a mistake is high.

sections.title: After this section you should be able to:
sections.excerpt: - Explain how feedback loops create incidents without any single bug - Explain why retries and timeouts are architectural decisions - Explain why AI monitoring, versioning, and rollback are part of system design

sections.title: Quality attributes and trade offs
sections.excerpt: Quality attributes are the "how" of a system, not the "what". The what is features. The how is performance, reliability, security, and everything that decides whether the system is usable and safe in real life.

sections.title: What this optimises for
sections.excerpt: - Decisions aligned to business and risk priorities - Clear justification for cost and complexity

sections.title: What this makes harder
sections.excerpt: - You have to say no to some goals and features - You must budget time for non feature work like testing and observability

sections.title: After this section you should be able to:
sections.excerpt: - Explain what a design is optimising for and what it makes harder - Explain how the same decision affects security posture and data governance - Explain why operability and testability are part of professional accountability

sections.title: Architecture as a professional discipline
sections.excerpt: Architecture is about trade offs. You are making choices under constraints and living with the consequences. The job is not to pick trendy patterns. The job is to make the system understandable, operable, and safe for its context.

sections.title: Choosing boundaries
sections.excerpt: - Decompose by **business capability**, not by database table. - Protect **data ownership**: the service that owns data enforces rules; consumers read via contracts. - Prefer asynchronous integration for resilience; reserve sync calls for user journeys that need immediacy.

sections.title: Transformers and attention as information routing
sections.excerpt: Attention is weighted routing, not memory. The context window is a hard wall, not a soft suggestion.

sections.title: Large language models as probabilistic systems
sections.excerpt: LLMs optimise likelihood, not truth. Fluency is not reliability.

sections.title: Retrieval, grounding, and embeddings
sections.excerpt: Grounding reduces hallucination; it does not erase it. Retrieval quality matters more than model size.

sections.title: Agentic systems and tool use
sections.excerpt: An agent is a loop: observe, plan, act, observe. Each loop compounds error.

sections.title: Detection and operations at scale
sections.excerpt: Prevention fails. Detection and response decide whether failure becomes disaster.

sections.title: Supply chain and systemic risk
sections.excerpt: Dependencies are attack paths. Trust is rarely isolated.

sections.title: Governance, safety, and limits
sections.excerpt: Governance is not paperwork. It is how we make decisions under uncertainty and accept residual risk honestly.

sections.title: What AI is and why it matters now
sections.excerpt: AI is a way of learning patterns from data so a system can make predictions, rank options, or automate decisions.

sections.title: After this section you should be able to:
sections.excerpt: - Explain what a model is and why it exists in a system - Explain what breaks when training data and real inputs diverge - Explain the trade off between automation speed and human judgement

sections.title: Data and representation
sections.excerpt: In AI, the word Data is recorded observations about the world. It is what the model learns from, not what we wish was true.

sections.title: After this section you should be able to:
sections.excerpt: - Explain why representation choices change what a model can learn - Explain what breaks when labels, groups, or context are missing from data - Explain the trade off between simple features and richer embeddings

sections.title: Supervised and unsupervised learning
sections.excerpt: When we say a model learns, we mean it changes its internal settings so it can make better guesses. It is not learning like a person learns. It is closer to practice. You show examples, it adjusts, and it gets less wrong over time.

sections.title: After this section you should be able to:
sections.excerpt: - Explain when supervised learning is appropriate and what it optimises for - Explain when unsupervised learning is useful and why evaluation is harder - Explain what breaks when people treat model outputs as understanding

sections.title: Responsible AI basics and limitations
sections.excerpt: AI systems can cause harm even when everybody is trying to do the right thing. The harm is not always dramatic. Sometimes it is quiet and personal. Someone is incorrectly flagged as suspicious. Someone does not get offered an opportunity. Someone is pushed into a bubble of content that makes them angrier and more certain.

sections.title: What this optimises for
sections.excerpt: - Automation speed and consistency for low risk tasks - Scaled assistance when humans have time and context

sections.title: What this makes harder
sections.excerpt: - Accountability if oversight is vague - Safe rollback when models drift or fail

sections.title: After this section you should be able to:
sections.excerpt: - Explain why models do not understand intent or truth and what breaks if you trust them blindly - Explain why evaluation and monitoring are continuous, not a one time step - Explain the trade off between AI automation and human oversight in high impact decisions

sections.title: Prompts and patterns
sections.excerpt: Prompts are not magic, they are instructions. A The instruction or input you give a model to get a response. works best when it is clear about the task, the format, and the boundaries. A A higher level instruction that sets the role, rules, and tone for the model. should be stable and reviewed, not improvised in production.

sections.title: Embeddings and vector search
sections.excerpt: Embeddings turn text, images, or audio into numeric vectors. A A numeric representation that keeps some meaning so similar items are close together. lets me compare ideas by distance. A A specialised database for storing vectors and searching them by similarity. powers semantic search, recommendation, and clustering.

sections.title: Retrieval with your own documents
sections.excerpt: Retrieval augmented generation, often called RAG, lets a model answer using your documents. It works by chunking documents, embedding the chunks, and retrieving the best matches for a query. The model then answers using the retrieved context.

sections.title: Simple agents that use tools
sections.excerpt: An A model that plans a sequence of steps and can call tools to reach a goal. is useful for multi step tasks, but it needs guardrails. A A request from the model to run a function or external action. should be limited, logged, and reviewed when risk is high.

sections.title: How to use this track
sections.excerpt: - Move through the four levels in order, or dip into a section you need for work right now. - Record a few minutes when you practise so CPD stays honest and local to your browser. - Share the labs with friends or a class and compare answers before you peek at mine. - Keep notes on what surprised you; that is where the real learning hides.

sections.title: Cryptography in practice
sections.excerpt: Crypto is only useful when it is applied correctly. Most organisations do not lose because the maths was broken. They lose because assumptions drift, keys leak, validation gets skipped, or somebody treats "encrypted" as a risk stamp that means "safe".

sections.title: Secure architecture and zero trust thinking
sections.excerpt: Zero trust is simple: never assume the network is friendly, always verify access, limit blast radius. Design where no implicit trust is granted based on network location. Breaking systems into small zones with tight policy reduces how far an attacker can move. Defence in depth still matters: identity, network, application, and data controls should stack.

sections.title: Detection, response and threat hunting
sections.excerpt: Detection closes the gap between compromise and action. A Security information and event management (SIEM), a platform that collects and correlates security events feeds alerts to a security operations centre (SOC), a team that monitors and responds. Good detection reduces how long an attacker stays unnoticed. Response follows a loop: triage, contain, eradic

sections.title: Governance, frameworks and your career
sections.excerpt: This section is the glue. It is temporary tooling in a way, because your first versions will be imperfect. That is normal. The point is to build a loop that makes the next version better.

sections.title: Security as an organisational capability
sections.excerpt: Cyber is not only for the security team. Product decisions create attack surface. Procurement decisions create supply chain risk. HR decisions shape onboarding and offboarding. Finance decisions shape tooling and staffing. Operations decisions shape patch windows and incident response. In real organisations, the best security work looks like good coordinatio

sections.title: Policies, standards, and reality
sections.excerpt: Policy, standard, procedure, and control are related but different.

sections.title: Incident response and learning loops
sections.excerpt: Incidents are noisy and emotional. Good teams make them boring on purpose.

sections.title: Measuring security without lying to yourself
sections.excerpt: Most security metrics are activity that looks reassuring but does not reduce real risk because they measure activity, not risk reduction. Counting completed training, scanned hosts, or patched tickets tells you effort. It does not tell you outcome.

sections.title: Ethics, trust, and long term resilience
sections.excerpt: Security decisions affect people. Privacy is not a feature. It is a power question. Consent matters because users rarely have equal bargaining power. A short term win that surprises users can become a long term trust loss. Trust is slow to earn and fast to burn.

sections.title: Foundations overview
sections.excerpt: Cybersecurity is about reducing real harm. It protects people, not just computers. It protects money, time, safety, privacy, and trust. When it goes wrong, it often looks ordinary at first. A bank transfer goes to the wrong place. A delivery address changes. A clinic cannot open a record. A small mistake becomes a big mess.

sections.title: After this section you should be able to:
sections.excerpt: - Explain what cybersecurity is protecting and why attackers often succeed - Explain the difference between threat, vulnerability, and risk in context - Explain what breaks when identity and process controls are treated as optional

sections.title: Assets, threats, and risk
sections.excerpt: An An asset is anything you care about enough to protect, like data, systems, people, time, and trust. It includes obvious things like customer records and laptops, but also things like staff time, reputation, and the ability to keep operating. If payroll fails on Friday, that is an availability problem. If a patient record is wrong, that is an integrity pro

sections.title: After this section you should be able to:
sections.excerpt: - Explain why risk is contextual and what breaks when controls are applied blindly - Explain how assets, threats, and vulnerabilities connect to real decisions - Explain why Identify work comes before tool buying

sections.title: Identity, access, and trust
sections.excerpt: Identity is now the security perimeter because work happens everywhere. Staff work from home. Phones are used for approvals. Vendors have access. Cloud services connect to other cloud services. The question is no longer only "is the network safe". The question is "who is this, and what should they be allowed to do".

sections.title: After this section you should be able to:
sections.excerpt: - Explain the difference between authentication and authorisation - Explain what breaks when identity is treated as a soft control - Explain why least privilege reduces blast radius during incidents

sections.title: After this section you should be able to:
sections.excerpt: - Explain why representation and parsing mistakes create security risk - Explain what breaks when systems disagree on how bytes should be interpreted - Explain why integrity controls depend on correct data handling

sections.title: Defence, detection, response
sections.excerpt: Prevention alone fails. Not because people are lazy, but because systems are complex. Something will slip. A password will leak. A laptop will go missing. A supplier will get compromised. Defence needs layers, and it needs feedback.

sections.title: After this section you should be able to:
sections.excerpt: - Explain why trust boundaries exist and what breaks when networks are assumed safe - Explain how metadata can leak behaviour even when content is encrypted - Explain why monitoring often starts with patterns, not secrets

sections.title: Confidentiality, integrity, availability and simple attacks
sections.excerpt: To keep this practical, we will use one simple frame: confidentiality, integrity, and availability, often shortened to CIA. Confidentiality means only the right people can see information. Integrity means changes are correct and visible. Availability means systems are there when needed. The purpose is not to memorise three words. The purpose is to ask better

sections.title: After this section you should be able to:
sections.excerpt: - Explain CIA as decision questions, not memorised words - Explain what breaks when identity is weak or integrity is not monitored - Explain why availability needs planning, not hope

sections.title: Human factors and governance
sections.excerpt: Humans are not the weakest link. Humans are the system. Most insecure behaviour is a rational response to a bad setup. If it takes five minutes to do the safe thing, people will do the fast thing. If approvals block urgent work, people will route around them. If security tools produce noise, people will ignore them.

sections.title: After this section you should be able to:
sections.excerpt: - Explain why humans are part of the system and what breaks when processes are unrealistic - Explain governance as ownership of trade offs, not documents - Explain why clear roles and rehearsed response reduce harm

sections.title: Chapter 3 Advanced Building secure systems that survive real attackers
sections.excerpt: Chapter 1 gave us the foundations of data, harm, and basic security properties. Chapter 2 showed how trust breaks across networks and how encryption, identity, and integrity are stitched back together.

sections.title: Threat modelling choosing what to defend and why
sections.excerpt: In earlier chapters, we talked about harm and trust. Threat modelling is where we turn that into a repeatable method. It answers a simple question: what could go wrong in this system, how would it happen, and what would we do about it.

sections.title: What threat modelling produces
sections.excerpt: A good threat model produces four things: A clear system boundary A list of assets worth protecting A set of realistic attacker goals A set of controls mapped to specific failure modes

sections.title: A minimal threat model structure you can reuse
sections.excerpt: 1 Describe the system in one paragraph 2 Identify assets 3 Identify entry points 4 Identify trust boundaries 5 Identify threats by category 6 Choose controls and note trade offs 7 Decide what you will monitor and what you will accept

sections.title: Questions
sections.excerpt: * What is the difference between an asset and a vulnerability * Why do trust boundaries matter more than components * Give one example of a threat that is not technical * If you had one day to improve security, how would threat modelling help you choose * Explain threat modelling to a colleague without using acronyms * Why is a threat model a living document

sections.title: Attack paths how real breaches unfold
sections.excerpt: Most breaches are not one clever trick. They are a chain of small wins. Attackers often start with access that looks harmless, then expand it.

sections.title: Questions
sections.excerpt: * Why is initial access often not the most damaging step * What is lateral movement in plain English * Why does privilege escalation change the whole incident * What does persistence mean and why is it dangerous * Where would you place detection if you could only place it in one stage

sections.title: Defence in depth designing so one failure does not end you
sections.excerpt: Defence in depth is the idea that no single control is trusted to be perfect. The design goal is that one failure does not become total failure.

sections.title: Control mapping as a discipline
sections.excerpt: A common failure in security programmes is controls without purpose. Each control should be traceable to a threat and a security property.

sections.title: Questions
sections.excerpt: * What does defence in depth mean in one sentence * Why is detection not a failure * Give an example of a control that reduces impact rather than likelihood * Why is recovery part of security * What is a single point of failure and how do you remove it

sections.title: Identity and access management where most real security lives
sections.excerpt: In many organisations, security is identity. If you can control who can do what, you reduce the blast radius of almost everything.

sections.title: Least privilege as a practical rule
sections.excerpt: Least privilege is not a slogan. It is a design constraint: People should have only what they need, only when they need it, and only for as long as they need it.

sections.title: Questions
sections.excerpt: * What is the difference between authentication and authorisation * Why does admin access change the risk model * What is a session and why does session expiry matter * Why is least privilege hard in real organisations * Give an example where usability pushes against security and how you would handle it

sections.title: Logs and telemetry evidence beats confidence
sections.excerpt: Many teams only realise they needed logs after a breach. Logs are not just for debugging. They are how you prove what happened.

sections.title: What makes a log useful
sections.excerpt: A useful log is structured, time ordered, and correlated. It answers questions without guesswork.

sections.title: Questions
sections.excerpt: * Why does logging support non repudiation * What is the difference between logs and monitoring * Why do timestamps cause confusion * What is correlation and why is it powerful * What is a false positive and why does it matter for detection

sections.title: Incident response staying calm when it is real
sections.excerpt: Security is partly design and partly behaviour under pressure. Incident response is the practice of doing the right things quickly when you do not know everything yet.

sections.title: Triage as a decision problem
sections.excerpt: Triage is not certainty. It is a decision under uncertainty. You often have partial signals.

sections.title: Questions
sections.excerpt: * Why is containment often the first priority * Why can deleting evidence make things worse * What is the difference between recovery and eradication * Why is communication part of incident response * What makes a good post incident review

sections.title: Vulnerability management turning unknown risk into known work
sections.excerpt: Most vulnerabilities are not cinematic. They are ordinary mistakes that remain unpatched.

sections.title: Prioritisation that makes sense
sections.excerpt: Prioritise by: Exploitability Exposure Business criticality Available mitigations Observed attacker behaviour

sections.title: Questions
sections.excerpt: * What is the difference between vulnerability, exploit, and incident * Why does exposure change risk * What is a compensating control * Why do patches sometimes increase risk temporarily * What is configuration drift

sections.title: Ransomware and recovery the reality check
sections.excerpt: Ransomware is not just encryption of files. Modern ransomware is a business model. It often includes data theft and extortion.

sections.title: Questions
sections.excerpt: * Why do attackers target backups * What does restore testing prove * What is a dependency and why does it matter for recovery * What is double extortion * What is the business decision behind paying or not paying

sections.title: Practice studio put it together
sections.excerpt: This practice studio is designed to feel like real work, not a quiz.

sections.excerpt: - Attack path grid: columns for access, execute, persist, escalate, move, impact. I place existing controls and see gaps. - Defence in depth rings: people, process, tech. I map each control to the ring and to CIA to spot single points of failure. - Identity flow: user -> IdP -> token -> app -> resource. I mark where logs must exist for authentication, author

sections.title: Threat modelling and attacker thinking
sections.excerpt: Security improves fastest when I can answer one question clearly: what matters, who might attack it, and how it could fail.

sections.title: Attack surfaces and common failure classes
sections.excerpt: Most breaches start with what is exposed, not with exotic zero days.

sections.title: Authentication, sessions and access control
sections.excerpt: Authentication answers who you are. Authorisation answers what you may do. Sessions remember you between requests. Mixing them up is why many breaches feel trivial.

sections.title: Logging, monitoring and risk thinking
sections.excerpt: Prevention is never perfect. Good detection shortens the time between a bad action and your response.

sections.excerpt: This level is for children, beginners and anyone who does not see themselves as technical. We start with the basics:

sections.title: Level 2 - Applied Cybersecurity
sections.excerpt: This level is for people who want to understand how systems fail and how we defend them. We build on the Foundations and start to think like attackers and defenders.

sections.title: Level 3 - Cybersecurity Practice and Strategy
sections.excerpt: This level is for people who want to think like security engineers, architects and leaders.

sections.title: Alignment with CISSP, NIST CSF 2.0 and Cyber Essentials Plus
sections.excerpt: This course is not an official exam preparation course and it is not endorsed by any certification body.

sections.title: CPD and professional development
sections.excerpt: I am writing these notes with Continuing Professional Development in mind.

sections.excerpt: You can use the material in a few ways:

sections.title: Identity centric defence and resilient platforms
sections.excerpt: Cloud makes identity the control plane. My job is to design guardrails, verify shared responsibility, and keep recovery paths ready.

sections.title: 1. Decision How to enforce least privilege in cloud
sections.excerpt: Permissions sprawl quickly. I design landing zones, baseline policies, and automated checks.

sections.title: 2. Decision Which dependencies are safe enough
sections.excerpt: Cloud stacks rely on many managed services and images. I identify critical dependencies and plan verification.

sections.title: 3. Evidence and readiness
sections.excerpt: I need proof that controls work: guardrail tests, break-glass drills, backup restores, and audit trails.

sections.title: 4. Ethics and accountability
sections.excerpt: Cloud decisions affect cost, performance, and user trust. I document trade offs and ensure privacy and accessibility are respected.

sections.title: Signals, certainty, and containment
sections.excerpt: I live in ambiguity. My decisions must balance false positives, false negatives, and business impact. Ethics matters when action affects users.

sections.title: 1. Decision Which signals matter most
sections.excerpt: Signal quality beats signal quantity. I prioritise signals that give high certainty with low noise.

sections.title: 2. Decision When to act
sections.excerpt: Acting too early can disrupt business; acting too late increases impact. I document thresholds.

sections.title: 3. Incident realism Build the timeline
sections.excerpt: title="Walk an incident timeline" description="Practise choosing containment, communication, and recovery steps under time pressure." >

sections.title: 4. Ethics and accountability
sections.excerpt: Containment can affect users. I apply least harm: preserve safety, respect privacy, and justify disruption.

sections.title: Role based decision making
sections.excerpt: This track is not about knowing terms. It is about making decisions that affect real people. Each page is a role. Each section is a decision. Each decision is tied to evidence and consequences.

sections.title: Roles
sections.excerpt: - Security Engineer /notes/cybersecurity/practitioner/security_engineer - Security Architect /notes/cybersecurity/practitioner/security_architect - Detection and Response Analyst /notes/cybersecurity/practitioner/detection_response_analyst - Cloud and Platform Security /notes/cybersecurity/practitioner/cloud_platform_security

sections.title: Designing for defensible systems
sections.excerpt: My job is to design systems that fail safely. I make assumptions explicit, reduce blast radius, and ensure the system is observable.

sections.title: 1. Decision Which assumptions are allowed
sections.excerpt: Architecture is mostly assumptions. I catalogue them, challenge them, and design controls to catch when they fail.

sections.title: 2. Decision How to prove the design is secure
sections.excerpt: Designs without evidence are optimistic. I need artefacts that show the design resists expected attacks.

sections.title: 3. Incident realism When architecture fails
sections.excerpt: title="Architecture failure rehearsal" description="Walk through an incident where a boundary fails. Decide what isolates, what alerts, and what recovers first." >

sections.title: 4. Ethics and accountability
sections.excerpt: Design choices affect safety, privacy, and inclusivity. I document impacts and seek consent when risk shifts to users.

sections.title: Decisions, evidence, and safe delivery
sections.excerpt: This role lives close to systems. The work is not to add controls randomly. The work is to choose controls that reduce risk measurably without breaking the product.

sections.title: 1. Decision What is the threat model for this change
sections.excerpt: I must define what I am defending and against whom. Without this, controls become theatre.

sections.title: 2. Decision What evidence proves the control works
sections.excerpt: Controls that cannot be tested are beliefs, not security.

sections.title: 3. Incident realism A timeline I must be ready for
sections.excerpt: title="Walk through an incident timeline" description="Practise containment, evidence preservation, and recovery decisions." >

sections.title: 4. Ethics and accountability
sections.excerpt: Security changes affect users. I keep friction proportional to risk. I avoid collecting unnecessary data. I am honest about uncertainty.

sections.title: From organisation to ecosystem
sections.excerpt: At earlier levels, digitalisation work was mostly inside one organisation. At this level it sits in ecosystems: supply chains, regulators, partners, platforms, and competitors share the same data flows and standards. A weak link in one place can hurt many others.

sections.title: Regulation, policy, and trust
sections.excerpt: Digitalisation at scale is shaped by regulation and policy. Regulation can enable change when guardrails are clear, or block it when rules are rigid or fragmented. Incentives can also push risk into the wrong places.

sections.title: Interoperability and cross-border thinking
sections.excerpt: As data, services, or platforms cross organisational or national boundaries, interoperability becomes central. It is not only technical; it involves shared meaning, process alignment, legal agreements, and operational coordination.

sections.title: Funding models and economic reality
sections.excerpt: Ambitious digitalisation needs realistic funding. The funding model is an architectural choice: project funding versus product and platform funding, central versus distributed investment, and charging models for platforms and data.

sections.title: Risk, resilience, and learning from failure
sections.excerpt: At this level we assume things will go wrong: systems fail, partners are compromised, regulations change, and some projects miss targets. The question is how we design for resilience and how we learn.

sections.title: Stewardship and long-term digital health
sections.excerpt: Stewardship recognises that digital choices today shape options for years. Data, platforms, and standards can become de facto public infrastructure. Skills, culture, and trust take time to build and can be lost quickly.

sections.title: Practice and reflection
sections.excerpt: questions={[ { q: "Why is it not enough to think about digitalisation within a single organisation at the advanced level?", a: "Because value, risk, and data flow across ecosystems, so a failure in one place can harm many others." }, { q: "How do regulation and policy shape digitalisation rather than simply constrain it?", a: "They set guardrails, incentives

sections.title: What digitalisation really is
sections.excerpt: Digitalisation is the deliberate redesign of how an organisation creates value using digital technology, data, and new ways of working.

sections.title: Why digitalisation matters
sections.excerpt: Digitalisation matters because expectations are higher, complexity is greater, and competition and scrutiny are sharper. People compare every service to the best digital products they use daily. Manual processes cannot keep up with data, regulation, and risk.

sections.title: Digitisation vs digitalisation vs digital transformation
sections.excerpt: Plain: Converting analogue information into digital form, such as scanning paper into PDF. Formal: Transforming analogue artefacts into digital representations without altering the underlying process.

sections.title: Data as a strategic asset
sections.excerpt: Data becomes an asset when it is correct enough to trust, accessible enough to use, governed enough to protect, and connected enough to create insight. Treating data strategically means deciding who is responsible, how it is collected, stored, shared, measured, and used safely.

sections.title: People and culture
sections.excerpt: Culture is the hard part. Systems succeed only when people trust them, know how to use them, and are supported to change habits. A digital culture shows up in the questions people ask: do we use data to decide, do we share information, do we test ideas, do we treat security and privacy as design constraints.

sections.title: Processes and technology foundations
sections.excerpt: If you automate a broken process, you get a faster broken process.

sections.title: Planning and maturity
sections.excerpt: Digitalisation is a journey in three horizons: short term visible wins, medium term shared platforms and data foundations, long term operating model change. Maturity models help if used to decide realistic next steps, not to chase a score.

sections.title: Observing digitalisation in practice
sections.excerpt: Digitalisation must be observable. It should show up in usage of digital channels, time saved, platform adoption, and indicators of data quality. Measuring change is part of doing digitalisation well.

sections.title: From foundations to design
sections.excerpt: The beginner page established that digitalisation is about value, people, process, data, and technology working together. At this level the questions change from “what is digitalisation” to:

sections.title: Vision, outcomes, and value
sections.excerpt: A lot of strategies fail because they start with technology. I start with a small set of clear outcomes that matter to real people.

sections.title: Operating model and capabilities
sections.excerpt: Digitalisation changes how the organisation runs. An operating model describes how people, process, technology, and governance work together to deliver value.

sections.title: Platforms, data, and architecture for digitalisation
sections.excerpt: Technology now becomes more concrete but remains strategy led. The question is which shared platforms support the capabilities and outcomes we need, how data moves safely, and what architectural approach keeps change easier rather than harder.

sections.title: Governance, funding, and risk
sections.excerpt: Digitalisation touches risk, money, and responsibility, so governance becomes central. Governance here is not long policy documents; it is clear answers to who owns the roadmap, who can approve platforms or major changes, how data and privacy decisions are made, and how security standards are enforced.

sections.title: Roadmapping and prioritisation
sections.excerpt: Even with a clear vision, operating model, and platform view, we cannot do everything at once. Roadmapping is the sequence of what changes when and why. Dependencies matter: analytics needs data quality first; identity should stabilise before modernising every small application.

sections.title: Practice and reflection
sections.excerpt: This dashboard gives a feel for the signals a digital leader might track: adoption of digital channels, use of core platforms, progress against roadmap milestones, and basic quality indicators. Strategy and measurement belong together.

sections.title: Architecture beyond a single system
sections.excerpt: At scale, architecture shapes organisations as much as it shapes software.

sections.title: Architecture and organisational structure
sections.excerpt: Systems mirror communication paths.

sections.title: Platforms, ecosystems, and digitalisation
sections.excerpt: A platform is an architecture that enables others to build safely and quickly.

sections.title: Resilience, failure, and risk
sections.excerpt: Design for failure because it is inevitable at scale.

sections.title: Governance without stagnation
sections.excerpt: Too little governance creates chaos. Too much governance kills innovation.

sections.title: Architecture as long-term stewardship
sections.excerpt: Good architecture leaves the system healthier than you found it.

sections.title: Observing digitalisation in practice
sections.excerpt: Architecture must be observable. Digitalisation is visible through delivery speed, stability, change failure rates, and operational cost trends. Without metrics, digitalisation is wishful thinking.

sections.title: Why software architecture exists
sections.excerpt: Architecture exists to manage complexity over time and keep change affordable.

sections.title: What is a system
sections.excerpt: A system is parts plus purpose plus constraints.

sections.title: What software architecture is and is not
sections.excerpt: Architecture is structure and principles for hard-to-change decisions, not low-level details.

sections.title: Structure, components, and boundaries
sections.excerpt: Boundaries fail quietly. Good architecture makes them explicit.

sections.title: Quality attributes and constraints
sections.excerpt: Quality attributes shape structure more than features do.

sections.title: Trade-offs and architectural decisions
sections.excerpt: Every architectural decision is a trade-off. Be explicit.

sections.title: Architecture as a living discipline
sections.excerpt: Architecture evolves. Stasis is decay.

sections.title: Observing systems in practice
sections.excerpt: If you cannot observe a system, you cannot govern or improve it.

sections.title: From understanding to design
sections.excerpt: Designing architecture means: - Turning requirements into structure - Translating quality attributes into constraints - Making decisions with incomplete information - Accepting trade-offs explicitly

sections.title: Architectural styles and patterns
sections.excerpt: An **architectural style** is a named way of organising a system that reflects common solutions to recurring problems.

sections.title: Decomposition and responsibility
sections.excerpt: Decomposition is the process of breaking a system into parts. Good decomposition is the difference between a system that scales and one that collapses under its own weight.

sections.title: Quality-driven architecture
sections.excerpt: In real systems, architecture is driven by **quality attributes** more than features.

sections.title: Making and recording decisions
sections.excerpt: Architecture is a decision-making discipline. Each decision has context, options, trade-offs, and consequences.

sections.title: Documentation and architectural views
sections.excerpt: Architecture must be communicated clearly. One diagram is never enough.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.excerpt: Security protects confidentiality, integrity, and availability. Ask three quick questions: what must stay secret, what must stay accurate, and what must stay online? Those answers guide every control.

sections.title: Symmetric encryption
sections.excerpt: One shared key locks and unlocks data. It is fast and proven (AES), but the shared key must be exchanged safely. Think of a locker code: if it leaks, privacy is gone.

sections.title: Asymmetric encryption
sections.excerpt: Two keys: a public key to lock, a private key to unlock. Share the public key openly; never share the private key. This removes the need for a pre-shared secret.

sections.title: Hashing in practice
sections.excerpt: A hash turns any input into a fixed-length fingerprint. Small input changes produce large output changes. Hashes support integrity checks and password storage (with salts and slow functions).

sections.title: Quick check
sections.excerpt: - Which part stays secret in asymmetric encryption? - Why does symmetric encryption not solve key exchange on its own? - When would you choose hashing instead of encryption?
